docs.title: Professional Tally Light System
docs.text: Tally Hub is a modern, professional tally light system designed for video production environments. Built with TypeScript and featuring a beautiful web-based admin panel, Tally Hub provides reliable tally light control for professional video mixers including OBS Studio and vMix.

docs.title: 🎯 Why Tally Hub?
docs.text:
Tally Hub bridges the gap between expensive commercial tally systems and DIY solutions, offering:

  • Professional Grade: Enterprise-level reliability with real-time tally updates

  • Modern Interface: Beautiful gradient-based admin panel with real-time monitoring
  • Flexible Deployment: Run on any computer or server with Node.js
  • Open Source: Fully customizable and community-driven

docs.title: 🏗️ Architecture
docs.text:
Tally Hub uses a modern hub-and-spoke architecture:

graph TB
    VM[Video Mixer<br/>OBS/vMix] --> TH[Tally Hub<br/>Server]
    TH --> WS[WebSocket<br/>Clients]
    TH --> UDP[UDP Devices<br/>ESP32/M5Stick]
    TH --> API[REST API<br/>Third Party]

    WS --> WEB1[Web Tally #1]
    WS --> WEB2[Web Tally #2]

    UDP --> ESP1[ESP32 Tally #1]
    UDP --> ESP2[ESP32 Tally #2]
    UDP --> M5[M5Stick Tally]

    API --> CUSTOM[Custom Integration]

Benefits of this approach:

  • Centralized Control: Single point of configuration and monitoring
  • Scalable: Support for unlimited tally devices
  • Reliable: Hub manages connections and handles device failures
  • Flexible: Mix and match different device types
  • Professional: Enterprise-grade monitoring and management

docs.title: 🚀 Quick Start
docs.text:
Get your Tally Hub system running in minutes:

WindowsmacOS/LinuxManual Installation 
# Download and run the startup script
Start Tally Hub.bat

# Make executable and run
chmod +x "Start Tally Hub.command"
./Start\ Tally\ Hub.command

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/tallyhubpro/Tallyhub.git
cd Tallyhub

# Install dependencies
npm install

# Start the server
npm run dev

Then visit http://localhost:3000/admin.html to access the admin panel!

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for Tally Hub system problems.

docs.title: "Port already in use" Error
docs.text:
Error: listen EADDRINUSE: address already in use :::3000

Solution: 1. Check if another Tally Hub instance is running 2. Change the port in configuration: 

# Set custom port
export PORT=3001
npm start
3. Kill any process using port 3000: 
# Find process using port
lsof -i :3000

# Kill the process (replace PID)
kill -9 <PID>

docs.title: "Node.js not found" Error
docs.text:
Solution: 1. Install Node.js 16 or later from nodejs.org 2. Verify installation: 

node --version
npm --version
3. Restart your terminal/command prompt

docs.title: Permission Denied (macOS/Linux)
docs.text:
Solution: 1. Make startup script executable: 

chmod +x "Start Tally Hub.command"
2. Allow execution in System Preferences (macOS) 3. Run with sudo if necessary (not recommended)

docs.title: Cannot Connect to http://localhost:3000
docs.text:
Check these items:

  1. Server Status: Ensure server is running and shows "✅ Tally Hub ready"
  2. Firewall: Allow Node.js through firewall
  3. Network: Try http://127.0.0.1:3000 instead
  4. Browser: Clear cache and cookies, try incognito mode

docs.title: Blank Admin Panel
docs.text: Solution: 1. Check browser console for JavaScript errors (F12) 2. Disable browser extensions 3. Try a different browser (Chrome/Firefox/Edge) 4. Clear browser cache completely

docs.title: Cannot Access from Other Devices
docs.text:
Solution: 1. Find Server IP: 

# Windows
ipconfig

# macOS/Linux  
ifconfig
2. Use Server IP: http://192.168.1.100:3000 (replace with your IP) 3. Firewall Rules: Ensure port 3000 is open 4. Network: Ensure all devices on same network

docs.title: "Connection Failed" Error
docs.text:
Check OBS Settings: 1. Tools → WebSocket Server Settings 2. Enable "WebSocket server" 3. Note the port (usually 4455) 4. Set password if desired 5. Restart OBS after changes

Check Tally Hub Configuration: 1. Host: Use localhost or 127.0.0.1 2. Port: Match OBS port (4455) 3. Password: Enter exact password from OBS 4. Test Connection: Use admin panel test button

docs.title: "Authentication Failed" Error
docs.text: Solution: 1. Check password in OBS WebSocket settings 2. Leave password empty if none set in OBS 3. Restart both OBS and Tally Hub 4. Case sensitivity: Passwords are case-sensitive

docs.title: "Cannot Connect to vMix" Error
docs.text:
Check vMix Settings: 1. Settings → Web Controller 2. Enable "Web Controller" 3. Note the port (usually 8088) 4. Allow external connections if needed

docs.text: Tally Hub includes a modern web-based firmware flashing tool that works directly in your browser using the Web Serial API.

docs.title: Flashing Process
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Flash Page
  2. Open your browser and go to: http://localhost:3000/flash.html

  3. Or click the "Flash Firmware" button in the admin panel

  4. Select Device Type

  5. Choose your device: ESP32-1732S019 or M5Stick C Plus

  6. The correct firmware will be automatically selected

  7. Connect Device

  8. Connect your device via USB
  9. Click "Connect" and select the correct serial port

  10. Most devices appear as "CP210x" or "CH340" USB Serial

  11. Enter Download Mode (if required)

  12. ESP32-1732S019: Hold BOOT button while clicking RESET

  13. M5Stick C Plus: Hold side button while connecting USB

  14. Flash Firmware

  15. Click "Flash" to begin the process
  16. Monitor progress in real-time

  17. Do not disconnect during flashing

  18. Verification

  19. Device will restart automatically
  20. Check the device display for the Tally Hub logo
  21. Device should appear in the admin panel within 30 seconds

docs.title: REST API
docs.text:
For mixers not directly supported, use our comprehensive REST API:

# Set tally states manually
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/tally \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"source": "Camera 1", "state": "program"}'

# Get current tally states
curl http://localhost:3000/api/tally/status

docs.title: WebSocket Events
docs.text:
Real-time integration for custom applications:

const ws = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:3000');

// Listen for tally state changes
ws.on('message', (data) => {
  const update = JSON.parse(data);
  if (update.type === 'tally_update') {
    console.log(`${update.source}: ${update.state}`);
  }
});

// Send tally updates
ws.send(JSON.stringify({
  type: 'set_tally',
  source: 'Camera 1',
  state: 'program'
}));
